thread.title: La. governor candidates make final pitches in person, on TV
thread.title_full: La. governor candidates make final pitches in person, on TV - FOX 8 WVUE New Orleans News, Weather, Sports, Social

author: cbs8
title: La. governor candidates make final pitches in person, on TV
text:
By MELINDA DESLATTE
Associated Press BATON ROUGE, La. (AP) - Candidates for Louisiana governor are crisscrossing the state and filling the airwaves with their final pitches, hoping to drum up interest from undecided voters for Saturday's election.
None of the four major contenders is expected to top 50 percent, so a Nov. 21 runoff will decide which man follows term-limited Bobby Jindal into office.
Republican U.S. Sen. David Vitter has campaigned as front-runner, but his poll numbers have slipped. Republican rivals - Public Service Commissioner Scott Angelle and Lt. Gov. Jay Dardenne - are trying to rally enough support to pass Vitter.
Democratic state Rep. John Bel Edwards appears to have locked up a runoff spot.
Six other statewide races are also on the ballot, along with four constitutional amendments. Polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. Saturday.
